criticReviews.criticPost: Just when you think this will end up being one long strung out plotline, Vincent ends up helping Cat with his beast senses.
My issues with the relationship drama aside, it was still lovely to have Beauty and the Beast back.

The opener successfully reset some of the grievances from Beauty and the Beast Season 1 and should allow the characters to forge a new path, while still maintaining the things we enjoyed the most: intrigue, friendship and (especially) romance.
Beauty and the Beast returns to The CW for its sophmore season with a whole new look, higher stakes, and a different kind of beast.
This one is just plain daffy, a bland, badly-written, indifferently-acted cop drama with unconvincing supernatural overtones.
This is the most convoluted, ill-conceived hour on the new schedule.
A new but forgettable TV treatment for an old story.
The premise couldn't have been any sillier if it included a singing teapot.
The pilot's hint of a connection between the beast's condition and the murder of Catherine's mother offers the promise of future depth.
Beauty and the Beast won't hurt all that much to watch, but the dialogue and plot stretches can add up to a lot of little ows.

That's just one of many unintended laughs you'll get from the overheated, badly written, wretchedly acted and unconvincing drama, which makes mincemeat out of the traditional beauty and the beast fairy tale.
Even paired with the tonally compatible The Vampire Diaries, it will take more than love's true kiss to cure what creatively ails this "Beast."
It's tough to imagine how anyone could make a more ham-fisted wreck of a remake of 1980s CBS fantasy series Beauty and the Beast than The CW's effort.
I suggest anyone with a taste for this sort of story get their hands on the DVDs of the original series' first seasons. The original Beast was a beauty. This one's a bust.
There's no scene-to-scene logic, just looking and yearning and styling to sad rock music.
The script plays like something a cat clawed to shreds and then some poor production assistant tried to piece together.
The premise is recycled and dangerously worn out, leaving very little for the plot to cling to.

CW has managed to negate both the fantasy and the morality [of the original], while sending an unintended message to its young female audience about the attractiveness of men with anger management issues.
It may sound ridiculous to recommend a terrible show in a review, but seriously, The CW's Beauty and the Beast is so bad it has to be seen.
It's the kind of show one can barely remember watching by the time the opening credits are done on what follows it.
Hilariously bad.
It's all truly terrible. And the fact that they even try to throw in a bit of somber 9/11 sentimentality? Revolting.
It is all so dreadfully familiar.
It's entertaining enough.
Perhaps best of all is the simple fact that twelve seasons in, It's Always Sunny is still wholly dedicated to making us laugh.
It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia is in the midst of yet another outrageous season.

"The Gang Turns Black" absolutely worked, finding Always Sunny drawing from the creative well that has made this such an enduring brand for over a decade and counting. It was funny, it was creative, it was irreverent, and, more importantly, it was risky.

Even when the show slightly misfires, it still manages to find laughs in unlikely places, while its unflinching, creative approaches to original ideas keep us engaged, entertained and wondering what misadventures the Gang will be caught up in next.
We're twelve seasons in and the show is trying new things. This is good.
The Gang, as ever... have a Globetrotters level of mastery of shenanigans, crudity, comic violence, and all-around awfulness.
It's clever, fearless ad well-meaning, while only occasionally cringe-inducing.
It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia hasn't lost what made it great in the first place.

Rarely do comedies last as long as this one has, and rarer still do they continue to challenge themselves as well as their viewers. Judge it however you like, but the gang has made it impossible to ignore Sunny in 2017.
The episode is risky, to be sure. But despite its illusion of being ribald, the premiere has a dirty secret: meticulous, thoughtful commentary, cleverly snuck in between low-brow antics.
Maybe it wasn't the best season the show has ever had, but if they can keep creating episodes such as the finale, it's still one of the best comedies on television.

Season 11 of It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia appears to be somewhere between more of the same and a continuing natural progression, which is by no means a complaint. I mean, it would be weird if the characters grew too much, right?
It still felt like Sunny, but there was a new electricity crackling through it. Season 10 didn't quite match that fervor, though, and Season 11 seems to be much the same.
It was all glorious.
The show may still be living on the fringe, but it -- along with its devoted viewers -- wouldn't have it any other way.

This 11th season is like watching the Harlem Globetrotters. They're doing difficult, outrageous things that -- thanks to talent, practice, and the sense that this is where they truly belong -- look absurdly easy.
The series reflects some of America's problems as if through a distorted funhouse mirror.
This episode had everything I wanted. I expected to see a delusional scenario where the characters stay true to themselves. This episode has it in spades.

Now that Always Sunny has joined the elite list of TV comedies that lasted 10 seasons or more - like Cheers, Friends, and M*A*S*H* - what better way to kick off its tenth season than with an episode where the Gang is piss drunk the entire time.
There's a reason the show has lasted this long. It can be funny. Disturbingly funny.
The five actors are by now so attuned to both their characters and the show's underlying philosophy that this tightrope balancing act has come to look easy.
The 10th season of It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia doubles down on off-format episodes that tweak the show's trademark formula.
Binge-watch episodes, and a gonzo compassion begins to seep up through the filthy surface.
It may not be everyone's cup of tea, for sure, but you gotta admire the chutzpa, at the very least. Well played, Sunny. Well played, indeed.
The jokes are mean-spirited, and the characters are horrendous, and you love them unconditionally because of it.

Ah, welcome back Always Sunny. You might be hit or miss, and getting a bit long in the tooth, but there's just something so refreshing about re-entering your world of constant cruelty and tasteless tomfoolery.

It's almost comforting in a way. The world might change, but the basic personalities of these schemers, cutthroats and loveable villains never do. They're outlandish. They're mean-spirited, and they're still really damn funny.
Driven by needs and emotions that are grubbily petty, ugly and selfish, it also happens to be delightfully funny: Even the meanest forms of humanity can jerk you into unexpected fits of laughter.
Sunny... gets its ninth season off to a strong start with a typically perverse episode.
Becoming the big dog hasn't cost Sunny its bite. It's only gotten meaner and funnier.
On par -- or at least within sight -- of 'Sunny's' glory days, before in-jokes and constant recycling set in.
The season nine premiere was fairly average by It's Always Sunny In Philadelphia standards, but still great when compared with the rest of television comedy.
Sunny is now in its ninth season, but is not showing its age.
Sustaining such a satirical balancing act for eight years should earn creators Rob McElhenney and Glenn Howerton (and their co-stars) a place in the comedy pantheon.
Welcome back to television's funniest display of human cruelty.
Sunny is back and, while maybe not as strong as the show's peak, it's at least as funny as last season and maybe even smarter.

[The cast's] neurotic efforts to scheme their way to happiness, fame, and fortune continue to coincide with skewed views on a variety of real-world issues that blend well with the show's onslaught of crude, scattershot humor.
It's still silly, random, offensive and hilarious.
Don't get hung up on the (lack of) plot: Sunny is all about the severely messed-up relationships between these horrible, but hilarious people.
Eight seasons in, it still feels great to slum it with this gang.
There's still comedy to be mined from Dennis and Dee misremembering their clearly effed-up formative years.
Yes, Sunny is just as dark and crazy as ever. I just wish it was a little more focused in its wit and a little less familiar.
It's been 10 long months since we last saw The Gang and, man, they are a sight for sore eyes.
It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia has become the Energizer Bunny of cable TV sitcoms, a hyperactive, enduring burst of awkward hilarity and imprudently cooked-up schemes.
Seven seasons later, Day, Howerton, and McElhenney aren't bothering with point A.

I've found Sunny to be more hit and miss in the past couple of seasons, but damn did Season 7 open strong. Hopefully this is an indication of things to come, because if so, this could be an epic season.
If the writing feels down a notch, the cast haven't lost a step.
After six seasons, it's clear the gang is doing something right. Why stop denim-boiling and whore-banging now?
In the first two exuberantly crude episodes, he [Rob Elhenny] proposes marriage to a hooker and eats ham from a toxic spill. In such grossness is greatness.
It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia already has its target audience locked in, and if you aren't a fan of the show as it is, season seven will do little to change that.
It's not the message we watch the show for. We watch it for these morons doing what they do best: making us laugh.
It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia is vicious, fearless, and without peer in terms of where it's willing to go to get a laugh.
Ah, It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia is back. Does everyone else feel the warmth?
Sunny has matured into a subversive, ridiculously over-the-top show that manages to keep its brain active while tweaking social and political correctness. That's no mean feat for a comedy.
It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia's cubist approach has a veritable monopoly on neo-neanderthal repulsion-as-comedy.
They've created a niche show full of conniving, backstabbing yet lovable characters so they might as well follow their formula and wring out all the comedy they can.
There were a lot of gimmick-lite plots that sometimes didn't cohere all too clearly but always had enough straight comedy to prop them up.

There's a reason this show has lasted five... seasons, and it's because these lazy, stupid, insensitive bastards are worse people than the cast of Seinfeld, if that's actually possible, and yet they're so much more loveable.
Sunny may not be the most highbrow comedy on television, but it's arguably the one with the highest density of actual laughs.
Season 5 brings more of the same, but the characters are so well delineated and the performances are so solid that more of the same is a good thing.
Sunny is playing to its strengths: using pop culture conventions to provide a jumping-off point for meta-riffs on their implausibility.
At least as funny as Danny DeVito's Twitter account. And with nearly as much naked Danny DeVito.
"Sunny," which has markedly improved over its four seasons, is certainly much better than any of the network comedies that will debut in the next couple of months.
Is it a truly great show? I wouldn't go that far, but it's funny and unexpected and original, and that's much, much more than you can say for 95 percent of the comedies currently on the air.

At some point, the gang on "It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia" will no longer be able to top itself, no longer do or say things that are even more wrong than the last thing they said or did. It hasn't happened yet.
Despite its flaws, the series invariably has moments, and it's difficult not to root for any promising comedy given the difficulties plaguing the genre.
There's a seriousness to It's Always Sunny's clowning, but it's tied up not in messages-just in its sharp writing and its cast's delirious, brilliantly committed performances.
there's a slight but perceptible stylistic change that makes it less funny, even though it's still insane and inspired and original.
A show that has continued to prove it is willing to go further than almost any other in the name of comedy.
There's a lot of life in the old sitcom format yet, my friends. Witness It's Always Sunny In Philadelphia, which makes hilarious hay out of TV's hoariest genre.
There is a willful, even gleeful abandonment of political correctness in FX's spare, painfully funny comedy It's Always Sunny In Philadelphia.

Philadelphia is looking for a bigger score from its old pros. DeVito the dad just wants to be part of the gang, and the foursome, kicking and screaming and poking fun at this whole sitcom gang concept, makes room.
In real life, we would never want to know those often horrible people, but the cast make them incredibly fun to watch on TV, even as we gasp at the lengths (and depths) that they will go to.
It's set in a bar, but Cheers this ain't. Sunny is much more of a latter-day descendant of Seinfeld, with DeVito as the most gleefully selfish character in the bunch.
If you're prudish or just polite, in other words, you'll be turned off by all the happy offensiveness. If you're not turned off, though, you may be entertained, as I am.
After years of futility, the search for a top-notch, 20-something slacker comedy is over, and it took a basic cable network to crack the code.
The show, in fact, is a small-scale gem, its characters refreshingly realized and its topic not aggressively dark, as seems to be de rigueur in TV comedy now.
It is smug enough to think it's breaking ground, but not smart enough to know it isn't.
Younger viewers might find the physical hijinks funny, but the writing and subtle jabs at society's hang-ups will fly right over their head.
Despite their 20-something age bracket, the Sunny in Philadelphia gang have truly found their people.
